com.siperian.sif.client

Class EjbSiperianClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.siperian.sif.client.SiperianClient
      • com.siperian.sif.client.EjbSiperianClient
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    EjbClient

    public class EjbSiperianClient
extends SiperianClient
implements EjbClient
    Implementation of SiperianClient to communicate with Siperian Hub Server using EJB. Supports transactions. Gets better performance than HTTP or SOAP by serializing the request objects instead of using XML. (See package docs for overview and comparison.)

    Warning: Instances are not thread-safe, see notes in SiperianClient.

    Transactions

    This class supports transactions on the Siperian Hub. If you do nothing with transactions (CPM or JTA), this class will cause the Siperian Hub to operate just as it does if HTTP or SOAP is used; each request will he processed in its own autonomous transaction. If you need transaction support, see the notes below.

    The Siperian Hub EJB uses transactions with JTS (Java Transaction Service) as supported by the application server in use. The Siperian Hub EJB is configured with trans-attribute=Required, which means if there is an external transaction started (in your EJB or JTA code), that one will be used. However, if there are none (as in the case of a UI application), the Siperian Hub will use its own implicit transaction (similar to auto-commit in JDBC). Note, the application server and database use the transaction level READ_COMMITTED. Note, some SIF requests participate in transactions differently; see the docs for each request class's getTransactionAttributeType() individually, for example: ExecuteBatchGroupRequest.

    We strongly recommend against writing explicit transaction code if it can be avoided. The J2EE/EJB specification supports container-managed transactions (CMT) so such explicit coding isn't required.

    To use CMT, configure your EJB ejb-jar.xml with element "container-transaction" and "trans-attribute" such as "RequiresNew". See the documentation for EJB and your application server.

    The createTX(int) method is provided for convenience of explicit JTA (Java Transaction API) programming, however you are free to use JTA without that method. Additionally, this method is not allowed in a CMT context.

    For support with JTA or CMT transactions, see J2EE Transactions and documentation for your application server:

    • WebLogic JTA
    • Websphere JTA
    • JBoss Transactions

    Security

    The security of communications between processes (for when the network is not trusted) is handled differently by each application server. EJB can be made secure by configuring it to use a secure protocol.

    • WebLogic Security
    • Websphere Security
    • JBoss Guide

      • createTX

        public UserTransaction createTX(int timeout)
        For details about JTA and transaction support, see above.

        This is provided for convenience of explicit JTA programming, but you are free to use JTA without this method. This method is not allowed in a CMT context.

        Uses "java:comp/UserTransaction" to do lookup from the getInitialContext().

        Parameters:
        timeout - Transaction timeout in seconds. Pass 0 to use the container default.
        Throws:
        SiperianCommunicationException

      • createTX

        public UserTransaction createTX(int timeout,
                                boolean localTxContext)
        For details about JTA and transaction support, see above.

        This is provided for convenience of explicit JTA programming for jboss when transaction need to be managed between to remote jvms, but you are free to use JTA without this method. This method is not allowed in a CMT context.

        Uses EJBClient.getUserTransaction(nodeName).

        Parameters:
        timeout - Transaction timeout in seconds. Pass 0 to use the container default.
        localTxContext - Transaction scope. Pass true if transaction is to remain within the same jvm
        Throws:
        SiperianCommunicationException

      • createTX

        public UserTransaction createTX()
        Deprecated. Since XT. Use createTX(int) to specify the timeout.
        Creates the UserTransaction with the timeout set to 30 seconds.
        Throws:
        SiperianCommunicationException
        See Also:
